p: The relative magnitude of domestic versus international HCV transmission could be a key parameter for the success of isolated national treatment strategies. National microelimination and prevention programs can only be successful if a significant fraction of infections is acquired domestically, while international coordination becomes more important with frequent international transmission. Indirect genetic evidence from Switzerland suggests an important role of domestic transmission [ 19]. Switzerland is ideally placed to study international transmission due to its small population size, the high proportion of MSM followed within the Swiss HIV Cohort Study (SHCS; www.shcs.ch) [ 20], and its connections to international networks of sexual transmission [ 21, 22].
